sideA: He implementado fixes y features de extremo a extremo muchas veces.

sideB.text: I have implemented fixes and features end-to-end many times.
I have implemented fixes and features from end-to-end many times.
I've implemented fixes and features from start to finish many times.
I've often handled the complete implementation of features from beginning to end.
I have implemented fixes and features end-to-end a lot of times.

note:
[End-to-end] (as an adverb) and [from end-to-end] (as an adverbial phrase) are both very common technical and business terms. They mean covering all stages of a process, from the very beginning to the very end.

[From start to finish] and [from beginning to end] are excellent synonyms.

A literal translation like ~from extreme to extreme~ is incorrect.

Since the sentence describes past experiences ('He implementado...'), the Present Perfect tense ([I have implemented...]) is the most natural choice.

sideA: La última interrupción del servicio duró tres horas.

sideB.text: The last service outage lasted for three hours.
The service was down for three hours.
The duration of the last outage was three hours.
The last service interruption lasted for three hours.
The last interruption of the service lasted three hours.
The last interruption of the service lasted for three hours.

note:
**[102]**

Both [lasted for] and [was down for] are natural ways to express the duration of a past event.

Using [duration] is more formal and suitable for reports.

A common redundancy error is mixing verb forms: ~The outage was lasted for three hours~. The correct forms are [The outage lasted] or [The outage was three hours long].

'Service interruption' is a common compound noun and often sounds more natural than 'interruption of the service'. The preposition 'for' is optional when talking about duration (e.g., 'lasted three hours').

~The lasted interruption...~ (Incorrect: 'Lasted' is the past tense of the verb 'to last'. The correct adjective here is 'last'.)

sideA: Tengo una carga de trabajo bastante alta esta semana

sideB.text: I have a pretty heavy workload this week.
My workload is quite high this week.
I'm dealing with a heavy workload this week.

note:
**[109]**

[Workload] is the correct term for the amount of work.

The most common adjective to describe a large workload is [heavy]. [High] is also acceptable.

Common errors are literal translations like ~charge of work~ or using awkward adjectives like ~big workload~. The correct collocation is [heavy workload].

~I have a strong workload...~ (Incorrect collocation: We describe a workload as 'heavy' or 'high', not 'strong'.)

sideA: Gracias!, me alegraste el dia con ese comentario.

sideB.text: Thanks! That comment really made my day.
Thank you, you just made my day with that comment.
Thanks! That comment brightened up my day.
That's so kind of you, you've really made my day.
Thanks, you made my day with that comment.

note:
The most common and natural idiom is [to make my day].

A good synonym is [to brighten up my day].

A common error is a literal translation, which is incorrect: ~You alegried my day~ or ~You happied my day~. Another unnatural phrasing is ~That comment put me happy for the day~.

sideB.text: When do these temporary files get deleted?
When are these temporary files deleted?
When does the system delete these temporary files?

note:
**[107]**

For a plural subject like [these temporary files], the correct auxiliary verb is [do].

A common mistake is to use 'does' with a plural subject (~When does these files get deleted?~). Another error is mixing auxiliaries: ~When do these files are deleted?~ is incorrect.

~When do these temporal files...~ (Incorrect word: 'Temporal' is a false friend. The correct adjective is 'temporary'.)

sideA: Le preguntare a Mario acerca del problema.

sideB.text: I'll ask Mario about the issue.
I'm going to touch base with Mario regarding this bug.
I'll check with Mario about the problem.
I'm gonna ask Mario about the issue.

note:
The verb [ask] doesn't require the preposition ~to~. Correct: [I will ask Mario], not ~I will ask to Mario~.

The structure is [consult with someone ABOUT something]. ~Consult with Mario the problem~ is incorrect.

[Gonna] is a common, informal pronunciation of 'going to' (e.g., 'I'm gonna ask...').

sideA: Hicimos una solucion alternativa, hasta que lo demás se arregle

sideB.text: We implemented a workaround until the rest gets fixed.
We put a temporary fix in place until the other issues are resolved.
We made a workaround until the other things get fixed.

note:
**[109]**

[Workaround] is often paired with verbs like [implement], [put in place], or [make].

[Gets fixed] is a good example of the 'get-passive', which is common in technical speech. [Is fixed] is also correct.

A common error is using 'be' incorrectly: ~until the rest be fixed~. The correct forms are [is fixed] or [gets fixed].

(User question: 'rest' vs. 'resto') Yes, [the rest] is the correct translation for 'el resto' (meaning 'what is left over'). It is different from the verb [to rest] (descansar).

sideA: ¿Qué módulo modificó el equipo de desarrollo?

sideB.text: What module did the development team modify?
Which module did the dev team change?
What module was modified by the development team?

note:
**[3]**

This is an **Object Question**. We are asking about what received the action. The subject (the 'actor') is [the development team]. Since the subject is known, we MUST use the auxiliary verb 'did' to form the past tense question correctly.

~What module the development team modified?~.

~...modify to?~ (Incorrect: The verb 'modify' is transitive here; it acts directly on an object. It does not need the preposition 'to'.)

sideA: Yo noté que había algo raro.

sideB.text: I noticed there was something strange.
I noticed something was off.
I could tell something was wrong.
I noticed something weird was going on.
I saw that there was something odd.
I noticed something strange.

note:
[Something was off] is a very common and natural idiom for 'había algo raro'.

[Strange], [weird], and [odd] are all good synonyms for 'raro'.

A common error is ~I noticed that was something strange~. The word [there] is necessary: [I noticed (that) there was...].

Both [I noticed there was something strange] and the more direct [I noticed something strange] are correct.

sideB.text: This has happened before.
It's happened before.
This isn't the first time.
It had happened before.
It happened before.

note:
The Present Perfect [This has happened before] is used to state that an event occurred at an unspecified time in the past. [It's happened before] is a common contraction.

[This isn't the first time] is a very natural idiom with the same meaning.

Just like in the question form, the Past Perfect [It had happened before] is only used when referencing a time *before* another past event.

The Simple Past [It happened before] is also a correct and direct translation.

sideA: ¿Quieres que te hable hacerca de mi flujo de trabajo?

sideB.text: Do you want me to talk about my workflow?
Would you like me to tell you about my workflow?
Should I walk you through my workflow?
Do you want me to tell you about my workflow?

note:
**[109]**

The structure for '¿Quieres que...?' is [Do you want me to...].

[To walk someone through] something is an excellent phrasal verb **[16]** that means to explain a process step-by-step.

A very common error is a literal translation: ~Do you want that I talk about...~. This is incorrect in English.

sideB.text: We've prioritized other, more important ones.
We have prioritized more important ones.
We're focusing on the more critical ones first.
We've given priority to more important items.
We've prioritized more important ones.

note:
The Present Perfect [We have prioritized] or [We've prioritized] is the correct tense for a recent past action with present relevance.

[To give priority to] is a good alternative to the verb [to prioritize].

A common error is using 'more' incorrectly: ~We have prioritized the more importants~. The adjective 'important' comes *before* the noun [ones] or [items].

~...others more important~ (Incorrect word order: The adjective 'more important' should come before the pronoun 'ones' or 'items', e.g., 'We've prioritized more important ones'.)
